awd_titl_txt: Interaction of Lightning Electromagnetic Pulse with the Ionosphere
awd_abstract_narration:
The effect of lightning at the ground is obvious, such as when a tree is struck.  In the other direction, lightning also can have an impact on the layer of the upper atmosphere known as the ionosphere.  The ionosphere is high above the Earth's surface and is strongly affected by solar radiation.  One of the practical impacts of the ionosphere from the human perspective is the ionosphere's role in affecting the propagation of radio waves.  Studies have determined that lightning can affect the ionosphere through perturbations known as elves, halos, and sprites.  The research funded by this award will focus on the impact that lightning has on lowering the height of the ionosphere.   A graduate student will be funded by this award, furthering the development of the next generation of scientists.


The researchers propose to examine the occurrence of different patterns in ionospheric reflection height change within individual lightning flashes under both daytime and nighttime conditions. This will require acquisition of additional data (at least several hundreds of events), particularly at night. The researchers expect that many observed effects are influenced by lightning discharge intensity. The work will contain an attempt at modeling elves in order to explain the inferred lowering of the reflection height. A number of other issues will also be examined:  (1) changes in reflection height as a function of causative-return-stroke peak current and preceding interstroke interval, (2) correlation between magnitudes of the first sky wave and ground wave, and (3) effect on ionospheric reflection height of compact intracloud discharges (in cases when they occur in pairs).  The researchers will also search for differences in E field frequency spectra that could be attributed to the inferred differences in effective reflection heights.

por.por_cntn:
The primary findings and outcomes of NSF project AGS-1521747 (2015-2018) include the following:

1. First estimates of correlation between magnitudes of the first sky wave and ground wave, which has important implications for understanding recent attempts to use electromagnetic signals dominated by ionospheric reflections for estimating lightning peak currents (Said et al., 2010, 2013) in global lightning locating systems, such as GLD360. A moderate correlation (correlation coefficient = 0.61) exists between the magnitudes of first return stroke ground wave and its first skywave. For subsequent return strokes, the correlation coefficient is 0.38. Field measurements were performed at the Lightning Observatory in Gainesville (LOG), Florida.

2. Ionospheric reflection heights for a pair of compact intracloud discharges (CIDs) were estimated for the first time, and no change in reflection height after the first event was observed. CIDs are the most powerful natural producers of HF/VHF radiation on Earth.

3. The first unified engineering model for computing the electric field produced by a sequence of preliminary breakdown (PB), stepped leader, and return stroke processes, serving to transport negative charge to ground, was developed in colaboration with Dr. A. Nag of FIT.

4. New FDTD model of lightning interaction with the ionosphere has been developed in collaboration with Dr. Y. Baba and Dr. T.H. Tran. It differs from most other models in that it is based on a realistic return-stroke representation (not a Hertzian dipole) and covers the nearly complete return-stroke frequency range. This model is the first to allow one to examine the dependence of skywave waveforms on such key lightning source parameters as return-stroke speed, channel length, and current risetime.

5. The first simultaneous records of lightning currents and associated fields featuring ionospheric reflections for natural upward flashes were obtained in collaboration with coleagues from EPFL (Switzerland) and ALDIS (Austria). The fields were measured at a distance of 380 km, the largest distance at which natural upward lightning fields have been measured simultaneously with their causative currents.

6. Electric field waveforms produced by compact intracloud discharges (CIDs) and CG lightning return strokes (RSs) in the same thunderstorm over the Gulf of Mexico were measured at LOG and used for estimating the effective ionospheric reflection height. The results were found to be similar for those two types of lightning events. This is exciting because the methodologies for CIDs and RSs are quite different. Furthermore, the methodology for CIDs is widely accepted in the community, while the one for RSs is often questioned and criticized.

7. A low-cost system for measuring lightning electric field waveforms (Lightning Detection and Waveform Storage System or LDWSS) was developed and calibrated at LOG. The system has been operational in the Amazon region of Brazil since November 1, 2017. In 2018, two main modifications were implemented, including the improvement of effective dynamic range and the capability to detect lightning in different frequency bands. The improvements were achieved by using two pre-amplifiers working in parallel, a new processing (smart saving) algorithm, and programmable analog filters. As a result, a single, low-cost lightning electric field measuring system allows one to record both close and far lightning events with good amplitude resolution and without saturation, and study both wideband and narrow-band (for example, very low frequency) field signatures of lightning, without modifying the hardware.

Three UF graduate students participated in work on the project. All three defended their Ph.D. dissertations in 2016-2018. Every year, our group hosted the events (including LOG tours) within the Annual Junior Science, Engineering, and Humanities Symposia organized by the UF Center for Precollegiate Education and Training. The PI served as advisor (mentor) for 3 Visiting Scholars (Adonis Leal from Brazil and Drs. Han Li and Kun Liu from China) funded by their home universities/governments and 1 Fulbright Visiting Scholar (Dr. Dan Micu from Romania). In January 2018, Adonis Leal defended his Ph.D. Dissertation titled “Optimization of Lightning Electromagnetic Field Waveform Detection” at the Federal University of Para, Brazil. The PI was appointed and served as Co-Chair of his Ph.D. Committee. Dr. Leal recently received a faculty position at the Federal University of Para.

Research results are used in teaching the senior undergraduate/graduate course "Lightning" at the University of Florida. The PI published a new textbook, "Fundamentals of Lightning" (Cambridge University Press, 2016), which has been translated into Chinese in 2018. It has been selected as one of the best 50 translated (imported) books of the year in China, apparently the only one in the Geosciences category.

The project has facilitated international collaboration (particularly with researchers from Brazil, Japan, China, Romania, Austria, and Switzerland).

New insights into the interaction of lightning electromagnetic pulse (LEMP) with the ionosphere are important for developing advanced wave propagation models taking into account the variability of the ionosphere and for improving VLF communication systems.
